captions.text:
CHRIS HARRIS: The new Golf GTI
doesn't have a beard, but it

is lighter, faster,
and more efficient
than the car it replaces.

Now, many enthusiasts have
always thought that this car

is just too boring to wear the
GTI badge, but I've always
disagreed with that.

Does this Mark 7 version
change anything?

The Golf GTI is quite a simple
car, but it's one with a

complicated history and
a complicated set of
responsibilities.

On the one hand, it's the car
that should be everything to
all people.

It's the classless performance
car that does everything all
the time for all people.

But on the other hand, it's
a car that was once an

enthusiast's object,
a car that people
like me lusted after.

And then it became a car that
people like me slightly
laughed at.

And then more recently
again, it became
a car that we respected.

So within that, there's the
full range of emotions.

So when I come to test a car
like the Golf GTI, it's quite
difficult, really.
Who am I speaking to?

Am I speaking to the full
hardcore enthusiast?

I'm not sure that person
buys a Golf GTI.

Am I speaking to the casual
driver, the person who doesn't
really care?

Well, they wouldn't be watching
one of my videos.
I don't really know.
Actually, do you know what?

I think a lot of people that
know a lot about cars quietly
respect the Golf GTI.

And if they were given the
chance to own one car year

round, I think they'd look long
and hard at one of these.

So let's have a look
at the Golf GTI.
First of all, some numbers.

This car has 220 horsepower,
because it's the base GTI.

It doesn't have the performance
pack, which costs

another about 1,000 pounds
and gives you another 10
horsepower.
So we have 220.

We have 250 foot-pounds of
torque, a maximum speed

claimed at 152 miles an hour,
0 to 60 in 6.5 seconds.

It all seems entirely
reasonable and
acceptable to me.
Basic setup of the Golf?

Well, the Golf body, independent
suspension all the

way around, electric power
steering, and a turbocharged
four-cylinder engine.

It's becoming a kind of normal
recipe, isn't it?

But Volkswagen reckons
they've added some
abnormal stuff to this.

They've brought in people from
other projects, let's say,

within the Volkswagen group, a
man who was involved with the

GT3 RS, 3.8-liter version, the
Gen 2 one that we all loved.

Carsten Schebstat, he has
worked on this car.

And to me, initially, it feels
like a clever car on the road.
It feels nice and supple.

They haven't gone down the
crazy, hardcore, overdamped,
oversprung route.

And that has to be
a great start.

Now, even though we have an
open differential, you can

turn off the traction
control in this.

And it scrabbles its way
out of second gear
turns pretty well.

I wouldn't really miss
the diff on the road.

It's got a really
nice front end.
It's accurate.

Steering, as ever in the
electric way, doesn't have any

great sense of connection
to it.

But they're getting good
at this stuff.

I think we're going to be at a
point fairly soon where they

can start to replicate the feel
of hydraulic steering.

I think the actual weighting is
good, even though it does

shunt around a bit according
to speed.

It's an enjoyable car to drive
fast, but it's not a kind of

car that you decide to grow
horns and drive too hard.

However, if you do, its
competence comes through and
through and through.

This has been developed to the
nth degree in this car.

You can just tell they've spent
time getting all the

performance from it that
they possibly can.

There are three driving
modes in this new GTI.

Normally, this stuff doesn't
interest me because I think

you should just have
a suspension setup
and deal with it.

But this car's quite
interesting.
We start out in Comfort.

And I like cars in Comfort,
even cars with badges like

GTI, because they tend to
work better on the road.

So we've got this quite
long travel feel.
It's supple.

It feels really, really nicely
damped over these roads--
and comfortable.

It's not sort of irritating me,
but it doesn't feel too
sloppy and lazy.
It wants to change direction.
It's an agile car like this.

But it's rolling enough
to give me an idea of
what's going on.

If I go to Normal,
I don't have a
profoundly different car.

In fact, I still seem to retain
90% of that comfort,

maybe more, and I just
lose a bit of roll.
The steering remains sharp.

It's a variable ratio rack, so
I've got 2.1 turns, much more

resistance at low speed than
I have at high speed.

So in Normal, I think it's
rather nicely balanced.

In fact, I might leave
it in Normal.

This is the interesting
one for me, though.

If I go into Sport, normally
when I press the Sport button

in car, it's a button that
says, I'll tell you what.
Let's totally [BLEEP]

the dynamics of the car and
make it horrible to drive

unless you're on a really
flat racing track.

But no one drives a Golf
GTI on a really flat
racing track, do they?

But I'm now in Sport mode, and
this car has not been shafted.

I've got flatter cornering, but
I've retained a sort of
supple edge to the suspension.

It feels like that initial
spring rate, that initial

amount of spring, isn't too
harsh, almost like there's a

variable rate spring
on the car.
And so I'm cushioned.
And it's not unpleasant.
Yes, it's firmer.
Yes, I've got more control.

But it hasn't wrecked
it for the road.

I think that's a very important
distinction, because

all too often, Sport
mode wrecks things.

And in the Golf GTI on
the road, it doesn't.

The motor itself, well, you
can look at it two ways.

It's either a bit bland
and not that much fun.

Or it's ruthlessly efficient
and impressively smooth.

Four cylinders, to me, used to
mean quite harsh, but this is
smooth as you like.

And as for the turbocharging and
the throttle response, I
cannot fault it--
fourth gear, 80 clicks.

You put your foot down,
and it just goes.
I mean, really goes.

And it gives you the impression
of far more

performance than a car with a
claim of 0 to 62, time of 6
and 1/2 seconds.

And your gearbox, the
gearshift is lovely.

It makes me ask a few
more questions of
Renault, this does.

If Volkswagen can make a manual
gearbox for the Golf

GTI, a car which I think is more
often not specified with

a DSG gearbox, then why can't
they do a manual gearbox for
their Clio RS?
This is a lovely shift.

Short shift, but not too short,
very, very accurate.
The clutch pedal's nice.

In fact, the relationship
between the three pedals is
quite good.

And when you're pushing on the
heel and toe, it's quite
natural as well.

I've haven't driven the DSG yet,
but we might get a skid
in one of those tomorrow.

But we know all about that
gearbox and just how
efficient it is.

This five-door car with a manual
gearbox is a very, very
nicely balanced package.

But it has got a couple
of problems.

The first problem is its price,
and the second problem
is related to that.
It's not a cheap car.

If you were to buy this car
and specify it with five

doors, a DSG gearbox, and the
performance pack, you'd end up

with a car that cost
over 28,000 pounds.

And that drags it right into
BMW M135i territory.

Now, I know people think I'm
boring about that car.

But it has 300 horsepower
and probably weighs
a little bit less.

And it's performance is on a
completely different level to
the Golf GTI.

So I'm worried that the Golf
GTI's marketplace has been
taken away from it.

I can't really give you any
answer to that until I drive
the two of them back to back.

But it is interesting to note,
isn't it, that a near

30,000-pound Golf GTI is upon
us, and yet BMW has a

turbocharged six-cylinder
rival to that car in the
market already.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

CHRIS HARRIS: --the basic
layout of the car.
Well, this is--
[BLEEP].
What are those?
Bald sheep!
They look like Gollum.
Did you see those?
Scared me.
Start again.
MALE SPEAKER: It's Gollum!
CHRIS HARRIS: Wrong.
[INAUDIBLE]
Middle Earth.

title: Golf GTI Mk.VII Road Test. - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.text:
are you driving that on the road between the bear mountain bridge and 
peekskill? I grew up in that area and had to drive that to get to my 
girlfriend every week. loved that road. We all called it the goat trail 
growing up﻿
comments.author: Taylor Hughes

comments.text:
About the pricing, In America, A gti starts at $24395, already pretty well 
equipped, perf. pack is $1500 more. That's about the same as an equally 
well equipped focus st and around the same as a wrx. A m135 coupe starts at 
around $45000. So In the states this car's a bargain.﻿
comments.author: macaron3141592653

comments.text: out of respect lets look long and hard at the golf gti﻿
comments.author: armourdaddy805

comments.text:
When you said that the Golf GTI plays in BMW M135i territory, I couldn't 
believe you. But then I checked the UK Volkswagen und BMW websites and you 
were right! A GTI with Performance Package and DSG cost as much as a basic 
M135i Manual. In Germany the GTI costs 7.100 GBP less! (32.000€ vs 
42.000€). Buy your GTI in Germany and drive it to UK, its cheaper :DD﻿

The M135 i tried to kill JC on a straight line >.<..it is useless that

month if u drive that thing properly..whereas the golf..u simply buy it, 
get in it, start it, drive it, have fun in it and it will never ever go 
wrong..It is a real car with medium high capabilities, with a medium high 
price tag on it..

P.s: people DO NOT BUY THE DSG...if u gone have am automatic u may as well 
be better off with a corolla diesel..﻿

I'm in Arizona so I don't have to worry about winter driving. Yeah, 
starting around 50,000 miles, the Mercedes seemed to have something 
terrible go wrong once every two or three months and I still owed quite a

MK7. It's a great car that exceeded all of my expectations, and I don't 
feel like I had to take a cut in quality/performance to get a nice cut on 
my bill.

comments.author: Jose Assunção

comments.text:
An excellent review, though I have to disagree with Chris about the market 
niche for the GTI being usurped by BMW. The BMW 1-Series M is now gone. The 
2-Series base model, the 228i, is $32,100 without any options here in the 
States. The GTI base model 2-door, the S, is $24,395. That's quite a 
difference. And the 228i is a coupe and doesn't have the hatchback utility 
of the GTI. I don't really think they're proper rivals. 
If you want a major bump in performance you'd have to go for the M235i, and 
that starts at $43,100.﻿

rival the gti should be worried about, its a shame you dont get that car in 
the USA though

comments.author: Kevin Cheung

comments.text:
Thanks! Chris Harris was not lying. The car is a lot faster than the 220HP 
would suggest, in fact, the car is actually underrated and has been dyno-ed 
with 235 at the crank / 210 WHP, if there is traffic on the highway its 
hard to find places to fully utilize all the power. I wish there was more 
traction in first gear as my car came with Pirelli Cinturato P7 tires. A 
switch to summer tires should do it.

Turn in and line holding is phenomenal. I had a few other cars before, 
Lexus IS300, Acura RSX Type S (Integra), Honda Prelude, and this car has 
much better turn in and corner exit. I did not wait for the performance 
pack but once you hit the apex you can just put on the power and it holds 
the line.

Shifter a bitter notchy compared to Honda, but once I broke in the car it 
felt much better. Pedals are excellent, interior quality is also excellent, 
I got the leather package and really it's nicer than the IS300 I bought 
brand new back in the day. I would be happy to drive this for a few years 
and upgrade to the Golf R.
comments.author: Kevin Cheung

comments.text:
Congrats!!

And your comments so far?
comments.author: Yousuf Abrar

comments.text:
6.5 seconds for 0-60? Ive seen the auto version hit 6.0 with amateurs using 
the launch control, and Randy Probst hit 5.7 with the 6 speed version, and 
owning the mk7 stick, I will attest to the much lower 0-60. It's almost 
scary once the motor hits full boost, the perelli tires just scramble for 
any grip possible.﻿
comments.author: Frank Pawloski

comments.text:
Fantastic review, in my opinion. It's great to hear an articulate, 
insightful review of driving impressions. First video I've seen with this 
presenter and I'm looking forward to other reviews. Keep up the good work. ﻿

comments.author: gerrar46

comments.text:
Always said if you want a cheap sports car that can play with big boys you 
pick a WRX STI OR AN EVO ..  had both owned a evo 4, and 7 and an STI. 
Personally id go for the GTD ! VW is all about build to me. I own a bora 
tdi 150 of all things now lol but personally i love the performance and 
reliability i get from it. I do a lot of miles. I would not get back in to 
an evo or sti now. give me the GTD any day because its the best all 
rounder.. Im not sure what there like the new ones, but personally in 3 
years I've just done maintenance work on bora and its never let me down 
!The STI is another story, EVO was def a better driving machine but costly 
to run. The GTI should be VWs super car to me.. if its not pushing 300 bhp 
why bother ?? GTD is my next car cause i like a little comfort to for money 
now and and more miles for my money... ﻿

I think you hit the nail on the head when you say that most enthusiasts 
respect the Golf GTi...or any performance VW for that matter...but they 
don't drive one. I think that's because while they are well built, capable, 
etc, they are just a bit dull. They have a "German personality" i 
guess...lol.
All the people I know who are VW enthusiasts are lovely people, but, just 
like the cars, they are very serious and slightly dull. The kind of person 
that corrects your punctuation, or turns up to a function at the exact time 
it says on the invitation to the minute. VW's correct your 
punctuation...lol﻿

comments.author: Mrlolibre

comments.text:
But no VW can beat Camry in reliability.  Camry's are boring but reliable.  
VW's are fun but fall apart fast. Take your pick.
lol
comments.author: Coyote Man

comments.text:
+Coyote Man It depends on the VW. Passat was never reliable until the 
current generation. The TSI is beating Camry in Consumer Reports, for 
example. The Jetta and Rabbit/Golf have been pretty good since the MKV 
(prior to the current generation). People have hated on that car's 
5-cylinder engine for its NVH and fuel economy, but it has proven to be up 
there with Honda.Toyota and Nissan motors in terms of being hard to kill. 
We had one of those Jettas in my family, and it had no problems. Recently 
traded it in for a 2014 GTI, and no problems yet. It's high mileage for its 
age (approaching 50,000 already). We'll see.
comments.author: jaymum23

comments.text:
+Mrlolibre It isn't that bad. In my mk6 I've only had issues with potholes 
(quite a bit actually), cause I live in New Jersey. I don't baby my car at 
all. Just take care of the car and drive it well, the one or two extra 
problems you'll have with it are well worth it.
comments.author: macaron3141592653

comments.text: The specs say it's 42K or that is what the dealer will start with in price.

comments.text:

comments.author: Ivan Bosnjak

Exactly. Only time will tell if any car is reliable. But in the past WV's 
aren't that reliable. Their GTI is fun to drive too.
comments.author: Coyote Man

comments.text: +jaymum23 time will tell I guess.
comments.author: Matthew Sharpe

comments.text:
No! Consumer Reports' predicted reliability results, which consolidate 
their survey findings for the past three model years. What's more 
interesting is the long-term results, which they offer in chart form, but 
do not factor into this ranking. There are quite a few German cars that are 
proving to be well above-average from ages 4-10. Most of them are Mercedes, 
but there are some VWs, Porsches, BMWs, and Audis. The Audi A6 and Mercedes 
E-class are downright shocking for people like me who came of age in the 
dark ages of German cars. They are filled with red dots (above-average) in 
90% of the trouble spots, like you'd expect of a Japanese car. Speaking of 
Japanese, Nissan and Infiniti have started making absolute junk as of 2013. 
Almost everything they produce is well below-average. So you can't just 
assume based on country of origin. These things are incredibly fluid.
comments.author: jaymum23

comments.text:
+jaymum23 Are you citing IQS (Initial Quality Surveys) which German 
manufacturers traditionally do quite well at?

I'm not referring to quality control & initial impressions from the first 
3-6 months of ownership, I'm referring to extended reliability over the 
first few years of ownership and beyond, where German vehicles typically 
fall in the rankings year after year for the reasons I've already mentioned.
comments.author: Matthew Sharpe

comments.text:
+Matthew Sharpe Both Audi and Porsche are in Consumer Reports top-10 this 
year. These are not the VW brand (which is at number 17 out of 28), but 
they are owned and produced by VW, Audi was number 4 last year. They do 
make top-10s, and it's been increasingly frequent since around 2010. There 
was once a myth that German cars were all reliable because they drove and 
were engineered so well. This was shattered when they cut costs and 
produced unreliable trash in the 90s, riding on their old reputation. But 
now you're buying into the myth that we are still in that era of German car 
design. We've come full circle and there are quite a few very reliable 
German models available right now. The Passat TSI even surpassed the Camry 
in Consumer Reports. When was the last time that happened?
comments.author: jaymum23

comments.text:
+Coyote Man Audi has been in their top 5 for two straight years. Porsche is 
in the top 10. BMW and Mercedes were both above average last year; this 
year only BMW is, but expect MB to be back up after they work out the new 
S-class's bugs.
comments.author: jaymum23

comments.text:
If you look at Consumers Reports Annual Auto issues you see Japanese cars 
are the leaders in dependable transportation.  American and German and 
Korean cars fall behind the Japanese cars. That's a good 25 years of 
service records so it's hard to deny. I would expect anyone to buy a 
Japanese car because they are dependable not because they make your heart 
race. lol
comments.author: Coyote Man

comments.text:
20 years ago you could get Golf or any other VW change tires and pads and 
no worries. It could last 500k km without any problem. As a matter of fact 
i still know people who drives old Golf 1 or 2 without any problems (yes 
it`s 2014 and they still drive it in Serbia) but now a days you`r lucky if 
it lasts untill warranty expires. Me as a stubborn European and someone who 
loves German vehicles would say NO. Go for Koreans or Japanese, they might 
not have the history on their side but they sure have warranty !
comments.author: Shulcyo

comments.text:
I agree. In the final analysis, you drive what turns you on ... It's a very 
emotional decision.
comments.author: Coyote Man

comments.text:
+Coyote Man Let's not take this debate there. Most GTI buyers would be 
perfectly happy with the standard equipment, and that's what makes it so 
nice to live with. We had our GTI for $27k out the door with DSG, 18" 
optional wheels, and navigation (basically all you'd need in a GTI) back 
when the base price was $2k less than the current generation, and it's the 
4-door model. If you let yourself get completely ripped off by adding 
absolutely every last bit of options and accessories, then that's your 
problem. The amount of options these days are absolutely ridiculous and 
mostly unnecessary. That's also why when we recently ordered our Range 
Rover Sport Supercharged to replace our old and tired family SUV, we 
skipped the Autobiography trim and that ridiculous $6k sound system. In the 
end you'd get the same amount of enjoyment, but at least you wouldn't be 
throwing your car around corners knowing you spent $100 on some shiny valve 
stem caps or $500 for an iPod cable when you can just use Bluetooth. I 
guarantee you with $42k, you'd be able to get a decently equipped Golf R 
out the door. 

As for mechanical problems, Japanese cars these days are getting up there 
when it comes to cost of maintenance and/or repairs when needed. If you go 
to a shop, you'll get charged out the ass for labor no matter what you 
drive, and parts for newer Japanese cars aren't exactly cheap. If you want 
Japanese cars with low cost replacement parts, you basically have to pick 
the most common models like Civic, Corolla, Accord, Camry, etc. My Subaru 
hasn't been exactly cheap compared to the GTI, which turned out to be a 
very accessible car if you're mechanically inclined to do maintenance 
yourself instead of getting raped by stealers. But then again, I'm merely 
speaking from personal experience. If you wish to stick with Honda or 
Toyota, no one is forcing you to do otherwise.
comments.author: NuclearPenske7

comments.text: A fully  equipped GTI in the US is about $42K.
comments.author: Coyote Man

comments.text:
+NuclearPenske7 $22K? Where? They START at $48K here in Australia. That's 
Subaru STi money
comments.author: Eman Resu

comments.text:
We should be honest and say a GTI isn't $22K equipped a GTI is over $40K in 
the US.
Let's not lowball the suckers to sell the product.
I stick with Toyota and Honda for reliability. I agree every car has 
mechanicl problems sooner or later. All these cars are very expensive to 
fix these days also.
comments.author: Coyote Man

comments.text:
+Coyote Man Every car eventually develops problems, be it at 30,000 miles 
or 300,000 miles. We only have around 60,000 miles on each and I'm not 
going to say they're the most reliable cars ever, but German cars are 
certainly improving if you look at the increasing number of perfectly 
running German cars with high mileage in the past decade. If you're looking 
for a small, fun, and practical car for around $22,000, there simply isn't 
a better all-around package than the GTI, but ultimately it's your choice 
to compromise that by choosing other brands presuming that German cars 
can't be reliable. And they may not be as reliable as the much more basic 
Hondas and Toyotas, but they're damn nice things to live with and they 
always offer something new to play with. Don't get me wrong, my family's 
been buying Japanese cars exclusively for the past 30 years up until the 
GTI, and my personal daily driver is a '05 Legacy GT wagon right now which 
I regard as the last great wagon from Japan, but most new Japanese cars are 
simply quite boring.

comments.author: neil borodkin

comments.text:
I really like how he had to honestly slot the review at the outset.  There 
are the hard core GTI drivers who want nothing but the purest form of 
driving from the GTI.  Then there are those who want to know about why it's 
an all round car.  Finally those asking about it's practicality.

I think we're at the melding point between these segments;  if you just 
want utilitarianism, then the Golf VII is for you.  If you want the 
performance and the heritage; Golf GTI VII.  If  you want the ultimate 
performance and the heritage; Golf R VII.

So now it's possible (IMHO) to review the car as a GTI...purely for GTI 
enthusiasts...and hearken back to the 70's version...but remembering that 
the world is a different place now.  We need the airbags, ABS, traction 
control, stability, crash sustainability, fuel economy.﻿

comments.author: Ian Townsend

comments.text:
Best "complete package" car in it's class... Other try to imitate it, some 
make "hotter" versions, but none of them combine, style, quality interiors, 
performance, good chassis dynamics and practicality into one package. 
 Often anything that can out-power a GTi is a total pain to drive on the 
road, has a truly stupid interior with ridiculous "performance features" 
and an engine that's about to explode...  (Renault Meganne RS anyone) 
 Can't wait to see/drive the AWD R version whether it's VR6 powered or not.

VW's Iron-block 4-cylinder architecture has been proven time and time again 
to handle 2-3X the stock power without worry and if you're smart about 
who's products you use to mod it, you're actually adding strength to an 
already strong engine.  These cars STATED "tuning" as we know it and they 
still produce the best results for a FWD car when you crack them open.﻿

comments.text:
WRX is a great car, but they look like a Legacy from the front clip back 
now and they're about the same size.  

GTi might be the only car that's gotten LIGHTER in it's newest generation. 
 Why do all car companies think that a new model "has to" be bigger??? 
 Drives me nuts.  Still lots to love in the new WRX from the FA Turbo motor 
(makes the STI seem silly with its non-VVTi EJ motor), new 6-speed (even 
though it makes it slower it's finally a quality shifting unit), to a 
chassis that hands out .96g.

I'd still buy a GTi myself but I don't really think they're comparable cars 
until Subaru pulls their head out and makes either a Wagon variant or a new 
smaller Imprezza replacement.
comments.author: Nor Wester (4Rescue)

comments.text:
+buckyai I live in the Pacific NW and I ran a VW FOX Wolfburg that I'd 
"rally'd" out, for several years working on Mt. Hood here in Oregon (daily 
commute: 1500-6700ft in 2.5miles on a 2-lane FS road... with a 12% grade at 
one point).  2wd and I got to work every day with 4wds off the road 
everywhere. VW's work REAL well in the snow,  but yeah... Bad drivers are 
bad drivers and struggle on all surfaces.

Not knocking Scoobys either, I love he WRX too, just saying.  The GTi's 
chassis is my favorite (I've been building MK1 and 2 cars for years) but I 
love rallying at heart and the WRX/Scoobys are just plain staple cars here 
in the NW on and off the track.  Two great cars and the GTi's no more 
"practical" as the WRX wagon is quite good in that department as well.  I 
will say the GTi has the looks though, Subaru has gone "funky" as of late. 
 They grow on me, but the last gen and the new one have both made me kinda 
go "really???" at first viewing...
comments.author: Nor Wester (4Rescue)

comments.text:
+bob g  "If your a terrible driver it doesn't really matter what car you've 
got, if you know what your doing most anything will work (up to a point 
obviously)." couldn't agree more on that sir.

my intended reply was that, a 2 wheel drive with a good set of winter tires 
will do just fine.  loose/wet/splashy snow is "ok" to handle but tightly 
packed and mirror polished snow/ice? its a different story and that's when 
studded winter tires are ideal...from my point of view on where i live and 
that's why i prefer the wrx over the gti, now if i lived in FL, either will 
work just fine sir....

comments.text:
the car is so boring...you see normal golf's everywhere and the GTI doesn't 
even stand out a little which is exactly what you want from a hot hatch. 
and way too overpriced also, id rather get a Seat Leon Cupra instead which 
looks so much more aggressive﻿
comments.author: Alex Sotirakis

comments.text:
1 - if you buy a car to stand out you're an idiot. You should be buying a 
car based on how it drives

2- Not overpriced. Only people who think it is overpriced are people who 
look like hp and tq stats and that is it. You aren't paying for high power 
stats with a GTI, it's value comes in many other places
